content.content:
astro theme - growth with starter template, CSS-tailwind. color theme examples: cal.com (background light gray with
white high-contrast content boxes), relevanceai.com (long page layout, sticky menu, pricing comparison of 4 items,
affiliate program page, become a partner page styles, socrative.com - clean layouts, javascript images on assessments, clean 4 verticals pricing comparison, homebuddy ( dropdowns, content, SEO), mailbakery.com/blog (blog view of larger images of topics and a TOC on the side with LSA, contact form, and category boxes), brand colors (for client choices to have full color theme choices (but keep it very limited)), 123rf.com charts and graphics, dribbble.com (charts - (example: https://dribbble.com/shots/605727-Infographic-Agro-Chart-Illustration-data-visualization/attachments/640352?mode=media , dashboards),

---

## Component Architecture (Client Demo System)

### Pricing Tiers
| Plan | Price | Pages |
|------|-------|-------|
| Basic | $396 | 6 (Home, About, Services, Contact, Gallery, Team) |
| Add-on | +$69 | +1 page |

### Component Structure
```
/components/
├── core/        (all plans: Nav, Footer, Hero, ContactForm)
├── basic/       ($396: Gallery, TeamGrid, ServiceCards)
├── premium/     (upgrade: PricingTable, BlogLayout, Testimonials, FAQ)
```

### Demo Flow
1. Client picks trade type
2. Brand colors auto-apply
3. Toggle components by plan tier
4. Deploy via Coolify
### Typography
| Type | Options |
|------|---------|
| Headers | Titan One, Arial Black, Google Sans |
| Body | Trebuchet, Montserrat, Arial |
### Build Tools (Priority)
| Tool | Use |
|------|-----|
| GitHub | Template storage |
| Coolify | Deploy |
| Unsplash | Demo images |
| Docuseal | Contracts + JSON automation + signing (backup: Docusign, OneSign) |
| Cal.com | Booking embed |
| Tally.so | Forms → n8n |
| NocoDB | Client CRM |

content.content:
# CLAUDE RULES - MANDATORY - READ AT EVERY SESSION START

## RULE 0: TOKEN ESTIMATION (HIGHEST PRIORITY)

**BEFORE any search, task, or subagent call:**
```
Est. tokens: [number] | Task: [description] | Proceed? (Y/N)
```

- Wait for user approval on tasks >500 tokens
- Summarize data - NEVER dump raw output
- User pays for tokens - respect their money and time
- NEVER ignore this rule

## RULE 1: Subagent Delegation Score

**BEFORE starting ANY task, calculate this score:**

```
DELEGATE_SCORE = (Type × 0.25) + (Context_Risk × 0.20) + (Token_Savings × 0.20) + (Complexity × 0.20) + (Time × 0.15)
```

| Factor | 1-3 (Low) | 4-6 (Medium) | 7-10 (High) |
|--------|-----------|--------------|-------------|
| **Type Match** | No matching agent | Partial match | Perfect agent match |
| **Context Risk** | Needs full chat history | Some context needed | Standalone task |
| **Token Savings** | <500 tokens saved | 500-2000 saved | >2000 tokens saved |
| **Complexity** | Simple/quick fix | Medium logic | Complex/multi-step |
| **Time Needed** | <10 min | 10-60 min | >60 min |

**Decision:**
- Score **7-10**: MUST delegate to subagent
- Score **4-6**: Consider delegating, ask if unclear
- Score **1-3**: Do directly

---

## RULE 2: Subagent Assignment

| Task Type | Delegate To | When |
|-----------|-------------|------|
| Research/exploration | `researcher`, `Explore` | Finding info, docs, patterns |
| DevOps/Docker/infra | `devops-engineer` | Containers, deployment, CI/CD |
| Debug/errors | `debugger` | Test failures, bugs |
| n8n workflows | `n8n-workflow` | Automation design |
| Code review | `code-reviewer` | After writing code |
| Documentation | `doc-writer` | README, comments |
| Content creation | `content-generator` | Blog, copy, articles |
| Security check | `security-auditor` | Auth, input validation |
| Performance | `performance-optimizer` | Speed, bottlenecks |
| Data/SQL | `data-analyst` | Queries, analysis |
| Git operations | `git-specialist` | Complex git tasks |
| Architecture | `architect` | System design |
| API design | `api-designer` | Endpoints, schemas |
| Testing | `test-runner` | Run tests |
| Refactoring | `refactorer` | Code cleanup |

---

## RULE 3: Task Format (ALL tasks must have these columns)

| Column | Required | Description |
|--------|----------|-------------|
| Task_ID | Yes | Number |
| Task_Name | Yes | Description |
| Time_Hrs | Yes | Estimated hours |
| Tokens | Yes | Estimated Claude tokens |
| Success% | Yes | Probability of completion |
| ROI | Yes | Return on investment 1-100 |
| Ease | Yes | 1-10 (10=easiest) |
| Delegate | Yes | Score from Rule 1 |
| Status | Yes | Not started / % / Done / Blocked |
| Dependencies | Optional | Blocked by task # |

---

## RULE 4: Session Start Checklist

Claude MUST do these automatically:
1. Read NocoDB tasks: `curl -s -H "xc-token: QEkBy3A48Fzn6CW4FCaQHfVGICmC4_kaYEPtMR7k" "http://localhost:8080/api/v2/tables/micl8z8rf5h7cpm/records?limit=100"`

input.content:
# BuildRightPros.com - Static Astro Site
FROM node:20-alpine AS builder

WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm ci
COPY . .
RUN npm run build

# Production - serve static files with nginx
FROM nginx:alpine
COPY --from=builder /app/dist /usr/share/nginx/html
COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
EXPOSE 80
CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]

content.content: File created successfully at: /home/echo/buildrightpros-site/Dockerfile

content.thinking:
Now I need to deploy to Coolify. The user has Coolify at 5.75.146.160. I can either:
1. Use Coolify CLI
2. Use Coolify API

Let me check if I can connect to the Hetzner server and deploy via Coolify API. First, let me check if there's SSH access or if I should provide instructions.

Actually, for Coolify deployment, I should provide a script that can be run on the server or via the Coolify API. Let me create a deploy script.

input.content:
#!/bin/bash
# BuildRightPros Deploy Script for Coolify
# Run this on your Hetzner server (5.75.146.160) or via Coolify UI

# === OPTION 1: Coolify API Deploy ===
# Set your Coolify API token (get from Coolify Settings > API)
# COOLIFY_TOKEN="your-token-here"
# COOLIFY_URL="https://coolify.systemgoat.com"  # or your Coolify URL

# curl -X POST "$COOLIFY_URL/api/v1/applications" \
#   -H "Authorization: Bearer $COOLIFY_TOKEN" \
#   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
#   -d '{
#     "name": "buildrightpros",
#     "git_repository": "https://github.com/VercinGetorix447/buildrightpros-site",
#     "git_branch": "main",
#     "build_pack": "dockerfile",
#     "domains": ["buildrightpros.com", "www.buildrightpros.com"],
#     "port": 80
#   }'

# === OPTION 2: Manual Docker Deploy ===
echo "=== BuildRightPros Deploy ==="

# Clone/pull latest
if [ -d "buildrightpros-site" ]; then
  cd buildrightpros-site && git pull
else
  git clone https://github.com/VercinGetorix447/buildrightpros-site.git
  cd buildrightpros-site
fi

# Build and run
docker build -t buildrightpros:latest .
docker stop buildrightpros 2>/dev/null || true
docker rm buildrightpros 2>/dev/null || true
docker run -d \
  --name buildrightpros \
  --restart unless-stopped \
  -p 8081:80 \
  buildrightpros:latest

echo "=== Deployed! Access at http://localhost:8081 ==="
echo "Configure Coolify proxy to route buildrightpros.com -> port 8081"

content.content: File created successfully at: /home/echo/buildrightpros-site/deploy.sh

http:

    buildrightpros:

      entryPoints:
        - https
        - http
      service: buildrightpros
      tls:
        certResolver: letsencrypt
  services:
    buildrightpros:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://172.17.0.1:8081"
EOF
cat /data/coolify/proxy/dynamic/buildrightpros.yml'

input.prompt: Describe the layout structure: hero section height, alternating left/right content blocks, white text boxes with borders, background colors, and any customer stories section styling

content.content:
# Clerk.io Website Layout Structure

## Hero Section
The homepage features a prominent hero section with a tagline "The easiest way to grow your bottom line in e-commerce" positioned above call-to-action buttons. A phone mockup image showcasing the platform's features is displayed alongside the messaging.

## Alternating Content Blocks
The design employs alternating left-right layouts for product features:
- **Search section**: Text on left, search interface mockup on right
- **Recommendations section**: Testimonial and description on left, product suggestion mockup on right
- **Chat section**: User quote on left, chat interface graphic on right
- **Audience section**: Feature description on left, lifecycle diagram on right
- **Email section**: Customer testimonial on left, email recommendation mockup on right

## Design Elements
- White text boxes with subtle borders and shadows contain customer testimonials
- Background colors alternate between light neutral tones and white
- Responsive typography uses clamp functions for scaling across devices
- Icons precede section headings with consistent styling

## Customer Stories Section
The testimonials area features:
- Multiple review platform badges (Capterra, Google, Trustpilot, G2)
- Rotating customer quotes with profile images
- Star ratings accompanying each testimonial
- Company attribution below each customer story

## Additional Sections
- Client logo carousel with 20+ brand references
- Statistics display with animated counters (35.4% order value increase, 9.3x conversion improvement)
- Integration logos representing 15+ platform connections
- Free downloadable guides with form capture elements

I cannot provide direct image URLs from the content you've shared. The webpage content appears to be heavily minified CSS and JavaScript code rather than actual image listings or URLs.

To find contractor/construction images on Unsplash for your specified purposes, you would need to:

1. Visit unsplash.com directly
2. Search for terms like "contractor," "construction," "builder," or "tradesperson"
3. Filter results by image characteristics (composition, color, worker focus, etc.)
4. Copy the individual image URLs from the photo pages

The page title indicates this is an "Unsplash" resource for contractor construction pictures, but the actual image data isn't accessible in the code provided. You'll need to browse the website directly to locate and retrieve specific image URLs for your business needs.

input.prompt: Describe the layout structure of the customers page: grid layout, card design, filtering options, image sizes, text placement
Describe the right sidebar/vertical section: what elements are in it, categories, newsletter signup, recent posts, any widgets

content.content:
# Clerk.io Customers Page Layout Structure

## Overall Design Approach

The page employs a **testimonial-focused layout** rather than a traditional grid with filtering. Here's the structural breakdown:

## Key Layout Components

**Hero Section**
- Centers messaging emphasizing customer success with rating badges (G2: 4.8, Captera: 4.9)
- Displays certification logos horizontally

**Customer Logo Grid**
- Horizontal scrolling or flexbox arrangement of brand logos (Carlsberg, Jeep, Unisport, etc.)
- Demonstrates social proof through recognizable company names

**Testimonial Sections**
Multiple quoted sections organized by category:
- Conversion rate improvements
- Average order value increases
- Search engine feedback
- Product recommendations
- Email automation results
- Customer segmentation
- Service quality

Each testimonial follows a card-like pattern with quotes followed by attribution (name, title).

## Design Characteristics

- **No explicit filtering options** visible in the layout
- **Text-heavy** with emphasis on direct customer quotes (quotes capped at ~125 characters per the constraints)
- **Responsive typography** using CSS clamp functions for scalability
- **Minimal image usage** beyond logo displays
- **Quote formatting** as primary content structure rather than image-based testimonials

The page prioritizes **narrative social proof** over visual product showcases.

toolUseResult.result:
# Clerk.io Customers Page Layout Structure

## Overall Design Approach

The page employs a **testimonial-focused layout** rather than a traditional grid with filtering. Here's the structural breakdown:

## Key Layout Components

**Hero Section**
- Centers messaging emphasizing customer success with rating badges (G2: 4.8, Captera: 4.9)
- Displays certification logos horizontally

**Customer Logo Grid**
- Horizontal scrolling or flexbox arrangement of brand logos (Carlsberg, Jeep, Unisport, etc.)
- Demonstrates social proof through recognizable company names

**Testimonial Sections**
Multiple quoted sections organized by category:
- Conversion rate improvements
- Average order value increases
- Search engine feedback
- Product recommendations
- Email automation results
- Customer segmentation
- Service quality

Each testimonial follows a card-like pattern with quotes followed by attribution (name, title).

## Design Characteristics

- **No explicit filtering options** visible in the layout
- **Text-heavy** with emphasis on direct customer quotes (quotes capped at ~125 characters per the constraints)
- **Responsive typography** using CSS clamp functions for scalability
- **Minimal image usage** beyond logo displays
- **Quote formatting** as primary content structure rather than image-based testimonials

The page prioritizes **narrative social proof** over visual product showcases.

content.content:
# MailBakery Blog Sidebar Content

The right sidebar contains several key sections:

**Newsletter Signup**
A subscription form titled "Subscribe to our newsletter" with fields for first name, last name, email, and CAPTCHA verification.

**Categories**
A browsable list including:
- Guides & Tutorials (163 posts)
- Inspiration (58 posts)
- Reviews (11 posts)
- News (12 posts)
- Comics (6 posts)
- Exclusive (6 posts)
- Freebies (4 posts)
- Greetings (1 post)
- Staff (2 posts)
- Uncategorized (2 posts)

**Social Media Links**
Connected accounts on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and YouTube for audience engagement.

**Search Functionality**
A search bar allowing visitors to find specific blog content.

**Additional Widgets**
- "Are You an Agency?" section promoting MailBakery's pilot project service
- A call-to-action for free HTML email templates from the MailBakery Store
- Information about MailBakery's core services (template design, coding, and ESP integration)

The sidebar emphasizes community building through newsletter signups and social sharing while directing users toward key service offerings and browsable content categories.

Here are the search results for high volume SEO keywords related to contractor marketing and lead generation for plumbers, electricians, and HVAC companies:

## Key Findings

### Keyword Research Fundamentals
Keywords are the foundation of SEO because your efforts must target terms and phrases that HVAC consumers search for online. Therefore, neglecting keyword research undermines your broader SEO campaign.(no content)Keyword research tools like Ahrefs, Moz Keyword Explorer, and SEMRush can help you build a list of targeted keywords based on search volume, difficulty, and user intent.(no content)Keyword volume is the estimated number of users who search for a query per month. Of course, the metric is not 100% accurate, as no platform can access every query. Still, search volume gives you a general idea about a keyword's popularity. Keep in mind that local terms will have a lower volume.

### High-Intent Keyword Examples
Transactional keywords include "Emergency plumber near me" and "book HVAC repair online." Commercial keywords include "Best electrician [city]" and "roof repair cost [location]."(no content)Most people use search engines to find plumbing businesses by attaching words like "near me" or "city name" to their search queries, for example "emergency plumbing Minneapolis". This offers you a great opportunity to convert them if you rank for keywords relevant to your business location. You can even double your leads and increase sales by optimizing your site for these keywords.

### Long-Tail & Local Keywords
Long-tail keywords are highly specific phrases that users search for when they're past the early "shopping around" phases. For example, someone searching for "board and batten siding contractor San Francisco" is probably closer to hiring a contractor than someone browsing for "siding contractors in the Bay Area." They're also generally easier to rank for than broader terms with higher amounts of (less-qualified) search volume.(no content)Localized keywords include the name of the city, county, or state where your contracting services are offered and are more targeted to specific local audiences. Since contractors' services are location-based, these queries are essential for contractors such as plumbers, electricians, HVAC professionals, and more.

### Case Study Results
After working with an SEO agency, Quick Fix Repair's Google Maps performance saw a 98% boost for "near me" searches. For the Local Pack, Quick Fix now appears for 33 high-intent, high-volume terms.

### HVAC Keyword Resources
HVAC Marketing Xperts published a guide with the top 200 free HVAC keywords for contractors to boost leads by targeting the right keywords for SEO success.(no content)The most lucrative HVAC keywords target specific HVAC services, and most users add their locations to these keywords.

### Why SEO Matters for Contractors
Plumbers, HVAC contractors, and electricians need SEO because 90% of customers search online before hiring a service.(no content)Home Services SEO emphasizes local intent (e.g., "emergency plumber near me") and service immediacy. Strategies focus heavily on location-based keywords, Google Business Profile optimization, and review generation, because customers are often ready to book on the spot.
